Emergency Resources

Emergency
Contacts & Resources

Critical contact information and quick-reference guides for legal emergencies. Save these numbers and know your rights before you need them.

üìûEmergency Contacts

üö®

911 Emergency

URGENT

For life-threatening emergencies, crimes in progress, or immediate danger.

Available: 24/7

‚öñÔ∏è

ACLU National Hotline

American Civil Liberties Union - Report civil rights violations and get legal referrals.

Available: Business hours

üèõÔ∏è

National Lawyers Guild

Legal support for activists, protesters, and those facing political prosecution.

Available: 24/7 hotline for arrests

ü§ù

Legal Aid Society

Find Local Office ‚Üí

Free legal services for low-income individuals. Search for your local office.

Available: Varies by location

üíº

EEOC Hotline

Equal Employment Opportunity Commission - Report workplace discrimination.

Available: Mon-Fri, 8am-8pm ET

üè†

HUD Housing Hotline

Housing discrimination complaints and fair housing information.

Available: Mon-Fri, 9am-5pm ET

üí¨ Key Phrases to Remember

"I wish to remain silent."

Invoke your 5th Amendment right. Say this clearly and then stop talking.

"I want to speak to an attorney."

Invoke your 6th Amendment right. Police must stop questioning you.

"I do not consent to any searches."

Protect your 4th Amendment rights. Say this even if they search anyway.

"Am I free to leave?"

Determines if you are being detained or are free to go.

"Why am I being detained?"

Ask for the reason if police say you are not free to leave.

"I will not sign anything without my attorney present."

Never sign documents you do not fully understand.

üìãWhat to Do If Arrested

IMPORTANT: This is educational information only. Every situation is different. Use your best judgment and prioritize your safety.

üßò
Step 1

Remain Calm

Stay calm and do not argue, resist, or obstruct the officer. Keep your hands visible at all times.

ü§ê
Step 2CRITICAL

Exercise Your Right to Remain Silent

Clearly state: "I wish to remain silent" and "I want to speak to an attorney." Do not answer any questions after this.

üö´
Step 3CRITICAL

Do Not Consent to Searches

Clearly say "I do not consent to any searches." Even if they search anyway, your objection matters in court.

‚öñÔ∏è
Step 4CRITICAL

Request an Attorney Immediately

Say clearly: "I want a lawyer." Once you request one, police must stop questioning you. Do not sign anything without a lawyer.

üìù
Step 5

Remember Officer Details

Try to remember badge numbers, patrol car numbers, and agency names. This information is crucial for your defense.

üë•
Step 6

Identify Witnesses

If there are witnesses, try to get their names and contact information. They may be vital to your case.

üè•
Step 7

Request Medical Attention if Needed

If you are injured or need medication, request medical attention immediately. This is your right.

üìû
Step 8CRITICAL

Make Your Phone Call Count

You have the right to a phone call. Contact a lawyer or family member who can find you a lawyer. Calls may be recorded except to your attorney.

üîá
Step 9CRITICAL

Do Not Talk About Your Case

Do not discuss your case with anyone except your lawyer. Phone calls (except to attorneys) may be recorded.

üí∞
Step 10

Understand Bail Options

Ask about bail at your arraignment. You have the right to reasonable bail in most cases.
